titleStmt.title: workshop discussion on the European youth pact and the job situation

publicationStmt.publisher: Barbara Seidlhofer, Stefan Majewski, Ruth Osimk, Marie-Luise Pitzl
publicationStmt.distributor: VOICE Project, University of Vienna, Austria

availability.p: The Vienna-Oxford International Corpus of English (VOICE) was created by Barbara Seidlhofer (project director) and Angelika Breiteneder, Theresa Klimpfinger, Stefan Majewski, Marie-Luise Pitzl (project researchers). Minor revisions and corrections were made by Ruth Osimk. VOICE 1.1 XML is available for download at the VOICE Project's website http://www.univie.ac.at/voice/ under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported (CC BY-NC-SA 3.0) License (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-sa/3.0/). The original audio files are held at the Department of English, University of Vienna. 23 selected audio files are available as audio streams in the VOICE Online interface at the VOICE Project's website http://www.univie.ac.at/voice.
The recommended citation for VOICE 1.1 XML is:

p.bibl: VOICE. 2011. The Vienna-Oxford International Corpus of English (version 1.1 XML). Director: Barbara Seidlhofer; Researchers: Angelika Breiteneder, Theresa Klimpfinger, Stefan Majewski, Ruth Osimk, Marie-Luise Pitzl.

availability.p: The short citation for VOICE 1.1 XML is:

p.bibl: VOICE. 2011. The Vienna-Oxford International Corpus of English (version 1.1 XML).

availability.p: For further information about availability and copyright permissions, please see the README file included in the download package. For further enquiries please contact the VOICE Project at voice@univie.ac.at.

notesStmt.note: In this workshop discussion, which is part of a larger conference on the situation of young people in Europe, the speakers talk about their impressions of and thoughts on what the plenary speakers said in earlier sessions. Later they are divided into smaller groups to discuss this.

equipment.p: Portable minidisc recorder with electret condenser stereo microphone

namespace.name: http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0
namespace.tagUsage: Used to mark a stretch of speech commonly preceded and followed by a pause or by a change of speaker. A u is, however, not required to be bounded by a pause or a change of speaker, nor does it represent a turn in a conversation analytic sense. At a minimum, a u is some phonetic production or noise made by a given speaker or a group of speakers.
Used to mark a pause either between or within utterances. Used without dur attribute to indicate a brief pause up to half a second.

Used to mark lengthening of sounds and intonation (fall, rise). The following type attributes are used to mark:
lengthening
lengthened sounds intonation
a significant change in intonation, marked with the following function attribute for:
fall
falling intonation rise
rising intonation
Intonation may or may not coincide with syntactic boundaries.
Used to mark contextual information relevant to the understanding of the interaction or the interaction as such. The voice:desc attribute provides a short prose description of the contextual event.
Used to mark speech which cannot be transcribed with certainty, because it is difficult to hear or understand for the transcriber.

Used to mark the point at which some paralinguistic feature changes. The following attribute values are used to mark:
voice
voice quality
imitating
laugh
neutral
phone
reading
reading_aloud
sigh
singing
whisp
yawning
tempo
speed of utterance
a
accelerando l
lento neutral
neutral
loud
loudness
f
neutral
p

Used to mark text supplied by the transcriber because the original is unintelligible or needed to be anonymized. The reason attribute is used to mark:
unintelligible
unintelligible speech anonymization
anonymized speech
Used to mark speech which is stressed or emphasized in a way that goes beyond regular nuclear stress.

Used with different type attributes to mark:
typeoverlap
overlaps typeonomatopoeia
onomatopoeic sounds typeipa
transcriptions in the international phonetic alphabet

Used to mark laughter and other speaker noises and non-verbal feedback.
speaker_noise
coughing
nods
shakes head
smacks lips
sniffs
swallows
whistles
wordlike
laughing
Used with the type attribute set to spelt to mark words or word fragments which are spelt out, i.e. words whose constituents are pronounced as individual letters.

Used to mark other-continuation, i.e. whenever a speaker continues another speaker's u without a pause. Other-continuation is to be interpreted temporally and does not relate to form or content of the speakers' utterances.

namespace.name: http://www.univie.ac.at/voice/ns/1.0
namespace.tagUsage: Used to mark the beginning of a new audio track used in transcription (usually three minutes in length) and thus refers to the audio recording of the transcribed speech event.

Used to mark a pronunciation variation or coinage as described in the VOICE mark-up conventions [2.1].the VOICE mark-up conventions [2.1]. An existing word corresponding to the PVC may be provided within a commentcomment attribute within the voice:pvcvoice:pvc element. Additional phonetic transcription may be provided within a voice:ipavoice:ipa attribute within the voice:pvcvoice:pvc element.
Used to mark speech directed towards a particular speaker. The whowho attribute indicates the addressed speaker.

div.u: okay we can start good so this morning was a bit longer than yesterday so er lasting till er quite well into the afternoon so we don't have that much time left now to er finish our discussions it's in the working group er and also the x with er some er recommendation statements and then go into er the declaration that xxxx tonight erm the session so yesterday we discussed er precarious working conditions of young people and er what youth organizations are doing can do er to to address the to address the issue er also w- we also dealt with er discrimination discrimination of young people and also xxx discrimination base on er er on other erm erm on other issues erm today the er the discussion this morning on the youth pact was a bit mo- was more er a discussion on on policy development and politic coordination erm from we heard what er the people from the different member states er were saying er how they were trying to bring people from the different departments together er involving or more or less er youth organizations in the process erm and also it's the from er [first name3] [last name3] european commission we heard how the commission was trying to coordinate er this whole effort er from brussels erm maybe first er like yesterday we can start with a round of let's say impressions from the morning erm er because we have only er a limited amount of time trying to be concise and what is what would you think is the let's say the most imp- er what did you remember from the morning what er what was the most significant thing that you would also like to take up in the discussion this afternoon this is important things that you think we should
erm i give you a few seconds to think about it and then this somebody already came up with er a few ideas
i have er for me if i start

erm the er really important thought that was mentioned er was that erm young people are taught at schools and perhaps in organizations a lot of important knowledge er but then er nobody t- teach how to how to work how to get employed er so perhaps this this would be er the direction of putting this area er because now the n g os do it help to young people to employ er er so er perhaps this direction could be er searched how to er bring this topic to schools to to formal education system
to to teach children to children and youth to er be workers and to become workers and employers employers employees okay so the wrong words
can i translate this as how can the education system contribute to employment opportunities for young people or
yeah but but er very wide widely understood educational system formal and informal but
also with stress on formal and non-formal let's say
yeah for me it's as well the the question was how as an organization erm are we able to make possible er the meeting between the polical people and er the young people from the grass roots
mhm so how to bring everybody from the grass-roots level and policy makers together
i blame it on the xx erm
yeah if maybe if you can write in capital letters after that after what from the next question it may help
erm for me an interesting question was who's responsible er on the national level for the youth pact because erm i think [first name2] mentioned that in sweden it's the prime minister
and i think in austria it's only a ministry
question like you wan- you would like to know who is responsible or who should be responsible
yeah you you cannot say that
you can make another mention still presumably
if we're writing a paper we can say what we would like to see xxxxx whatever

erm and also that leads to the decrease of customer choice where it's therefore falls right into the hands of capitalism erm and it kind of all works hand in hand if we're gonna fight the wide picture we need to make sure that our young people erm to go forward and create their own erm businesses with their own sets of standards where we can implement
so how to encourage young people to set up their own business or is it not
or not to encourage but to give them a tool so that they can if they want to

x x x x that erm like the controversity between erm implementation at municipal level so that the youth pact will be er you know er more er liberated in depth that was e- er what i noticed that the youth pact has to be implemented at municipal level but also the problem that is erm h- has been noticed by the national government that there is a lack of erm coordination as well as between er different sectors as between er the responsible ministries i guess
and i guess erm the controversity between er er implementing at a municipal level even
erm e- er er create more fragmentation
in an in the policy of youth policy actually i think that maybe youth organizations er will have a a leading role maybe to er er coordinate erm
such policies at municipal levels or

across the different actors who are involved okay then we can anything else

those are the four questions erm again four as as yesterday erm when it comes to time we hav- we have th- the we have to end at six o'clock because we have to go back into er working groups then and i w- i would like to have
